The yellow sprout and white snow are not hard to find,
But the adept must rely on deep virtue and conduct.
The four images and five phases all depend on earth,
How could the three primals and eight trigrams leave *ren*?
Refining the numinous treasure, none can recognize it,
Dissolving all yin demons, no ghost can invade.
Should one wish to leave this secret in the world,
Not a single soul would be a true listener.

This chapter speaks of how those who cultivate the Dao must diligently refine virtue and conduct to establish the foundation of the elixir. The great path of the golden elixir can liberate one from the cage and transcend the three realms—this is the supreme, most authentic Dharma treasure. Without utmost virtue, how could one congeal the utmost Dao?

The true yang within *kan* is called the yellow sprout; the true yin within *li* is called the white snow. These two are the true medicines of the golden elixir. The true medicine must be transmitted by a true person, and the true person must revere virtue and conduct. Virtue and conduct are neither one nor two, like the two wheels of a chariot or the two wings of a bird. The truest virtue is nothing other than purity, clarity, loyalty, and filial piety—upholding the moral order. The truest conduct is nothing other than aiding the distressed, lifting the fallen, and benefiting all beings through expedient means. If one can cultivate both inwardly and outwardly, with inner and outer as one, one will naturally move heaven and earth, touch the spirits, and meet a true teacher to receive the true medicine. If virtue and conduct are lacking, even if one meets a true teacher and is given the true Dao, one will surely be unable to bear it, often perishing halfway or meeting ruin in the end. As the *Yinfu Jing* says: *"When petty men obtain it, they treat life lightly."*

According to the *River Chart*, metal, water, wood, and fire are the four images, and together with central earth, they form the five phases. Metal, water, wood, and fire all arise from central earth, and after completing one cycle, they return to central earth. The root of arising is here, and the root of return is also here. Hence it is said: *"The four images and five phases all depend on earth."* The three primals are primordial essence, primordial *qi*, and primordial spirit; the eight trigrams are *qian*, *kun*, and the six children. The three primals are but one primal, and the eight trigrams are but one Supreme Ultimate. The one emerges from the center, and from the Heavenly One, true water is born—this is truly the source of all transformations. Hence it is said: *"How could the three primals and eight trigrams leave *ren*?"* The above line refers to the center in the elixir path as true intention; the line below refers to the one in the elixir path as true lead. The true intention of the central yellow is still and unmoving, and body and mind naturally merge. From the void, the great medicine is born—this is called true lead. True lead is the golden elixir, formed by the union of the yellow sprout and white snow. From this, through repeated refinement, the mortal substance is transformed into numinous substance, and none can fathom it. Through ceaseless reduction, yin *qi* is dissolved into pure yang, and no ghost can invade. Without the power of the great medicine, how could this be achieved? Yet without deep virtue and conduct, how could one attain this?

Such secret teachings cannot be passed from father to son, nor from minister to ruler. Only one whose virtue and conduct are lofty, who has long-standing ties to immortality, can bear to receive them. In this vast world, who is a true listener? Even the patriarchs cannot help but sigh thrice at this! Their sighs for the rarity of true listeners are truly sighs for the difficulty of finding one who has accumulated virtue and conduct. *"Diligently seek the true lead,
Lest time slip by too easily.
Capture the earthly *po* to subdue the cinnabar mercury,
And the heavenly *hun* will naturally restrain the water-metal."*

This is truly called: *"When the Dao is high, dragons and tigers submit;
When virtue is weighty, ghosts and spirits revere."*
Once one knows that life is as enduring as heaven and earth,
Afflictions will no longer arise in the heart.

This chapter speaks of the wondrous efficacy of the golden elixir, which can indeed transcend the world. Building on the above, since virtue and conduct are sufficient to establish the foundation, the great medicine is not difficult to attain—one must eagerly seek the true lead. True lead is the primordial *qi* that comes from the void; it is the great medicine of the golden elixir. This medicine is most numinous and wondrous, not found within the four great elements of the body, yet it cannot be sought outside the body. One must use true intention to capture it. When the thought arises and enters profound stillness, the true lead is born of itself. Once obtained, life is established by oneself, and one will not waste time or squander the years. Though true lead is but one *qi*, it is initially formed by two substances. To merge two into one requires the work of inversion: first, capture the metal within the northern water to subdue the wood within the southern fire, then use the fire within the southern wood to restrain the metal within the northern water. Thus, metal and wood are united, water and fire are harmonized, and true lead is obtained. The wood within fire and the metal within water are the heavenly *hun* and earthly *po*—*hun* and *po* are the dragon and tiger.
chunks.overlap_context: ng the method of driving the tiger to join the dragon, one takes the true gold within *kan* and infuses it into *li*. When the gold returns to its nature, this is called the returned elixir, and the body of *qian* is complete. Hence it is said: *"Lead the White Tiger home to nurture it, / And bear a luminous pearl like the full moon."* This is the symbolic method of producing the great medicine of the golden elixir within the *kun* crucible. Further work lies ahead in the gathering and refining.

chunks.original_text: 身中之真龙真虎既伏，世间龙虎自无不驯伏矣； 身中之阳魂阴魄既归，世间鬼神亦无不归命矣。 此不特道业至高，抑亦德行至重，才能如此。 如此道高德重，便可提挈天地，把握阴阳。 天地有坏，这个不坏。 一切烦恼悉化为妙明真心，此非断烦恼而证菩提、烦恼即菩提也！ 性命俱了，此金丹大道，出世之极则也。 不识真铅正祖宗，万般作用枉劳功。 休妻谩遣阴阳隔，绝粒徒教肠胃空。 草木阴阳皆滓质，云霞日月属朦胧。 更饶吐纳并存想，总与金丹事不同。 此章言金丹大道迥绝旁门也。 上章言真铅之妙可以超凡入圣，学道者可不识真铅哉！ 真铅是先天一炁，从虚极静笃中来，虽似有作，其实无为，乃造化之根源，大丹之宗祖，非独修一物者可以并驾，并非搬弄后天精炁一切妄作妄为者可以幸致也。 一阴一阳各正性命，方称大道。 何须休妻？ 若独修一物，天地不交，真种无由生化矣，此休妻而阴阳否隔之象也。 浩然之气充塞天地，自然不假一毫外物帮补。 何消绝粒？ 若内不足而强绝外缘，未免馁在其中矣，此绝粒而肠胃空虚之象也。 草木金银喻身中浊物，如心肾肝脾之类； 云霞日月喻身中凡气，如精神魂魄之类。 此等皆后天渣滓，合之四象五行不过依稀仿佛而已，与先天一炁有何干涉乎！ 更有执呼吸为元气者，未免着于吐纳； 认思虑为元神者，未免着于存想。 岂知真息之息与不神之神合为一炁，返乎太虚，才是金丹大道，与此等旁门天渊迥别，不可不明辨也。 夫金丹即真铅也，世人既不识真铅，安识金丹？ 此章痛扫旁门，极其警策。 惜乎愚夫错认休妻一语，又流入采阴旁门，造下地狱种子，恰如避溺而投火矣。 哀哉！ 万卷丹经语总同，金丹只此是根宗。 依他坤位生成体，种在乾家交感宫。 莫怪天机具泄漏，只缘学者尽愚蒙。 若能了得诗中意，立见三清太上翁。
chunks.translated_text:
Once the true dragon and true tiger within the body are subdued, the dragons and tigers of the world naturally submit; once the yang *hun* and yin *po* within the body return, the ghosts and spirits of the world likewise offer their allegiance. This is not merely the highest attainment in the Daoist practice, but also the weightiest in virtue and conduct—only thus can one achieve such a state. With such lofty Dao and profound virtue, one may grasp heaven and earth and command yin and yang. Though heaven and earth may decay, this remains indestructible. All afflictions transform into the wondrous luminous true mind—this is not the severing of afflictions to realize bodhi, but rather *afflictions themselves are bodhi*! With both nature and life perfected, this is the Great Elixir Dao, the ultimate principle of transcendence.

He who fails to recognize true lead as the primal ancestor labors in vain with all his efforts. To dismiss one’s wife is but to sever yin and yang in vain; to abstain from grain is but to leave the stomach and intestines empty in futility. Herbs and trees, yin and yang, are mere turbid substances; clouds and mist, sun and moon, belong to the realm of obscurity. Even if one practices breath regulation and visualization, all such methods differ entirely from the work of the Golden Elixir.

This chapter declares that the Great Elixir Dao stands utterly apart from heterodox paths. The preceding chapter expounded the marvel of true lead, which enables transcendence from the mundane to the sagely—how can a cultivator fail to recognize true lead? True lead is the primordial *qi* of prior heaven, emerging from the state of utmost emptiness and profound stillness. Though it appears to involve action, it is in truth non-action—the root of creation and the ancestral origin of the Great Elixir. It cannot be equaled by the cultivation of a single element, nor can it be attained through the manipulation of postnatal essence and *qi* or any reckless contrivance.

Only when yin and yang each fulfill their nature and destiny does it merit the name of the Great Dao. Why dismiss one’s wife? If one cultivates a single element alone, heaven and earth do not unite, and the true seed has no means to arise—this is the image of severing yin and yang by dismissing one’s wife. The *qi* of vast integrity fills heaven and earth, naturally requiring no external aid. Why abstain from grain? If one’s inner resources are insufficient yet forcibly cuts off external sustenance, one will inevitably suffer inner depletion—this is the image of an empty stomach and intestines from abstaining from grain.

Herbs, trees, gold, and silver are metaphors for the turbid substances within the body, such as the heart, kidneys, liver, and spleen; clouds, mist, sun, and moon are metaphors for the mundane *qi* within the body, such as spirit, essence, *hun*, and *po*. These are all postnatal dregs, which, when aligned with the four images and five phases, are but vague approximations—what connection do they have with the primordial *qi* of prior heaven?

Some cling to breath as the primordial *qi*, inevitably fixating on exhalation and inhalation; others mistake thought for the primordial spirit, inevitably fixating on visualization. Little do they realize that the true breath’s cessation and the spirit’s non-spirituality merge into a single *qi*, returning to the Great Void—this alone is the Great Elixir Dao, utterly distinct from such heterodox paths. One must discern this clearly.

The Golden Elixir is none other than true lead. If people do not recognize true lead, how can they recognize the Golden Elixir? This chapter vigorously sweeps away heterodox paths, offering the most incisive admonition. Alas! Foolish men misconstrue the phrase "dismiss one’s wife" and stray into the heterodox path of yin cultivation, planting the seeds of hell—just as one flees drowning only to leap into fire. How lamentable!

The words of ten thousand elixir classics all converge on this: the Golden Elixir has but one root. Following the earthly position, it forms the generative body; the seed is planted in the heavenly palace of union. Marvel not that the celestial mechanism is fully revealed—it is only because scholars remain benighted. If one can grasp the meaning within this poem, one will immediately behold the Three Pure Ones and the Most High Lord.

chunks.original_text: 此章言金丹大道，为超凡入圣捷径，乃《悟真篇》上卷之结尾也。 前章言金丹作用迥绝旁门，可见只此一事实，余二即非真矣。 岂特此书为然，纵阅尽万卷丹经，亦只言此一事耳。 先天羲易提出乾坤坎离，已为丹经开山作祖，《道德》并《清静》诸经，惟宗自然，虽直指无为之道，而金丹作用已在其中。 《阴符》及《参同》诸书，要人返本，虽详示有为之功，然作用到头仍归自然大道。 至于关尹庄列之所阐扬，钟吕海蟾之所撰述，莫不皆然，无非究性命之根，以定金丹之宗而已。 所云金丹最的端者，此其根宗也。 金丹作用，篇中言之即详，统而论之只是产药于坤炉，结丹于乾鼎两言可尽。 以金丹言之，坎离始交而产大药，坤宫事也； 至于依时采取升入天谷引归黄庭，则属之乾家矣。 以还丹言之，采药入炉而用文火温养，坤宫事也：至于聚火载金交媾锻炼于昆仑顶上，则又属乾家矣，崔公所谓“产在坤，种在乾”是也，故曰：“依他坤位生成体，种在乾家交感官。 ”祖师剖露到此，可谓直泄天机矣，奈世人尚惑于旁门！ 或以彼我两家分乾坤，此与无间地狱作因缘者；
chunks.translated_text:
This chapter expounds the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir as the swiftest path to transcend the mundane and enter sagehood, serving as the conclusion to the first volume of *Awakening to Reality*. The preceding chapter demonstrates that the workings of the Golden Elixir stand utterly apart from heterodox paths—there is but this one truth, and the other two are not genuine. Not only does this text affirm this principle, but even if one were to peruse all ten thousand elixir classics, they would speak of nothing else.

The *Xianyi* of the Primordial Fuxi presents Qian and Kun, Kan and Li, establishing the foundational lineage of elixir texts. The *Dao De Jing* and the *Qingjing Jing*, revering naturalness alone, directly point to the Dao of non-action, yet the workings of the Golden Elixir are already contained within. The *Yinfu Jing* and the *Cantong Qi*, urging a return to the root, meticulously instruct in the practices of action, yet when their workings reach their culmination, they still revert to the Great Dao of naturalness. As for the teachings expounded by Guan Yin and Zhuang Lie, and the writings of Zhong, Lü, and Hai Chan, all without exception investigate the root of nature and life to establish the essence of the Golden Elixir. What is called the most authentic Golden Elixir—this is its fundamental essence.

The workings of the Golden Elixir are detailed within this text, but in summary, they can be encapsulated in two phrases: producing the medicine in the Kun crucible and congealing the elixir in the Qian tripod. Regarding the Golden Elixir, the initial union of Kan and Li gives rise to the great medicine—this pertains to the Kun palace. As for gathering it at the proper time, ascending into the Celestial Valley, and guiding it back to the Yellow Court, this belongs to the Qian household. Regarding the Returned Elixir, gathering the medicine into the crucible and nurturing it with the gentle fire pertains to the Kun palace; as for assembling the fire, bearing the metal, and refining through union atop Kunlun’s summit, this again belongs to the Qian household. As Master Cui said, “Produced in Kun, planted in Qian”—hence the lines: *“Following the earthly position, it forms the generative body; the seed is planted in the heavenly palace of union.”* The patriarchs have revealed this so explicitly that it may be called a direct disclosure of the celestial mechanism, yet the world remains deluded by heterodox paths!

Some divide Qian and Kun between self and other, thereby forging karmic ties to the Avīci hell.

Marvel not that the celestial mechanism is fully revealed—it is only because scholars remain benighted. If one can grasp the meaning within this poem, one will immediately behold the Three Pure Ones and the Most High Lord.

chunks.original_text: 或以脐上顶下两地分乾坤，此向黑山鬼窟作活计者； 岂非愚蒙之极乎！ 倘有智慧过人之士，参讯勤恪，神明忽告，当下豁然了悟，方知山河大地总是鼎炉，蠢动含灵悉皆药物，日用动静无非火候，三清太上即我本来法身，而立地成真作祖矣，故曰“若能了得诗中意，立见三清太上翁。 ”三清音，玉清、上清、太清三境真人也。 太上者，巍巍尊高先天真宰也。 凡夫—闻三清太上便惊惶无地，妄谓此乃天上至尊，断无我分，不知我之元精即玉清真人，即佛家所谓清静法身也； 我之元炁即上清真人，即佛家所谓千身亿化身也； 我之元神即太清真人，即佛家所谓圆满报身也。 举一即三，是名三清，会三归一，是名太上。 非三而三，非一而一，无上而上．真空不碍妙有，故曰“无极而太极”。 三本非三，一本非—，上本无上，妙有不碍真空。 故曰“太极本无极”。 此乃无上至真妙觉之道也。 祖师所云悟真者，悟此而已。 从前一切金丹作用，若炉鼎．若药物，若火候，到此总属筌蹄，何况旁门小乘？ 呜呼！ 苟非三教至人，其孰能知之哉！ 此卷已括尽金丹作用，以下不过引而伸之耳。 —路剖析次第秩然，到末了才直泄天机，作者注者双眼洞照，读者亦知之否耶？ （上卷总评） 卷中
chunks.translated_text:
Some divide Qian and Kun between the regions above the navel and below the crown, thus making their livelihood in the demonic caves of Black Mountain—could there be a greater folly? Yet should a person of surpassing wisdom inquire diligently with reverence, the numinous might suddenly reveal itself, and in that instant, all becomes luminously clear. Then one knows that the mountains, rivers, and the great earth are but the crucible and furnace; that all creatures, even the lowliest, are the medicine; that every movement and stillness in daily life is the firing time. The Three Pure Ones and the Most High are none other than one’s original Dharma-body, and standing firm, one becomes a realized patriarch. Hence the saying: *“If you grasp the meaning in this verse, you shall instantly meet the Three Pure Ones and the Most High.”* The Three Pure Ones refer to the perfected beings of the three realms: Jade Clarity, Highest Clarity, and Grand Clarity. The Most High is the majestic, venerable, primordial true sovereign.

The common person, upon hearing of the Three Pure Ones and the Most High, is struck with terror, mistakenly believing these to be the supreme deities of heaven, utterly beyond their reach. Yet they do not realize that their primordial essence is the perfected being of Jade Clarity, which in Buddhism is called the pure Dharma-body; that their primordial qi is the perfected being of Highest Clarity, which in Buddhism is called the thousandfold and myriad transformation bodies; and that their primordial spirit is the perfected being of Grand Clarity, which in Buddhism is called the perfect reward-body. To grasp one is to grasp all three—this is what is meant by the Three Pure Ones. To unite the three into one is what is meant by the Most High. It is not three yet is three; not one yet is one; without superior yet is superior. True emptiness does not obstruct wondrous existence, hence the saying: *“The Supreme Ultimate is without limit.”* The three are not truly three, the one is not truly one, the superior is not truly superior, and wondrous existence does not obstruct true emptiness. Hence the saying: *“The Supreme Ultimate is fundamentally without limit.”* This is the unsurpassed, most true, and wondrously awakened Dao. What the patriarchs call “awakening to reality” is nothing other than this.

All previous methods of the Golden Elixir—whether crucible, medicine, or firing time—at this point become but the fish-trap and rabbit-snare. How much more so the heterodox paths and lesser vehicles? Alas! If not for the perfected ones of the Three Teachings, who could ever comprehend this? This scroll has already encompassed all the workings of the Golden Elixir; what follows is but an elaboration. The path is dissected step by step with perfect clarity, and only at the end is the celestial mechanism directly revealed. Do the author and annotator see with penetrating vision? And do the readers likewise perceive it? *(General Remarks on the First Scroll)* End of Scroll One.

chunks.original_text: 七言绝句六十四首 七言绝句六十四首（以象卦数） 道自虚无生一炁，又从一炁产阴阳； 阴阳再合成三体，三体重生万物张。 此章言大道顺生之序也。 《道德经》云：“道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 ”只此数句，包罗万象，该括三教，惜未有知其解者。 大道本来无方无体，浑然太虚，不可道，不可名者也，强名之曰虚无，曰自然，曰未见炁然。 才谓之虚即实矣，才谓之无即有矣，才谓之自然即该具因缘矣，才谓之未见炁而元炁已生，道生一矣。 故曰“道自虚无生一炁”，周子所谓“无极而太极”是也。 一炁既分，其中便有清有浊，有动有静，动者清而上浮为天，静而浊者下凝为地，一生二矣。 故曰“又从一炁产阴阳”，周子所谓“分阴分阳，两仪立焉”是也。 从此天气下降，地气上升，二气交感，人生其中，二生三矣。 故曰“阴阳再合成三体”，周子所谓“乾道成男，坤道成女”是也。 只此一元之炁，充周布满，三才既备，品物咸亨，情与无情莫不各正性命，三生万物矣。 故曰“三体重生万物昌”，即周子所谓“万物生生而变化无穷”者也。 此章是祖师述《道德经》，特衍而明之，以为中篇六十四章纲领．所谓顺去生人生物者也，从此逆而返之，便是金丹大道。 万物芸芸各返根，返根复命即长存。 知常返本人难会，妄作招凶众所闻。 此章言学道者当知常返本也。 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 可见大道物物具足，矧人为万物之灵，可不思返本还源乎？ 倘能从日用常道颠倒求之，即此六根门头，根尘相对时，当下斩断意识，意识不行，六用皆息，所谓“一根既返源，六根成解脱”也。 从此一切有情无情之物，无不各返其根，而先天之命复矣。 命复而谷神不死者，终古常存矣，即太上所谓“万物芸芸，各归其根，归根曰静，静曰复命”是也。 归根复命之功，人人做得，而世人往往当面磋过者，只为不知常耳。 此道本至平而无奇，至澹而无味，不离日用，直造先天，是为太常。 人能一念回机，当下便同本得，才知常即返本矣。 奈何百姓日用而不知，昧却自家底平常心，往往厌常喜新，向外驰求，做出许多捏怪伎俩，阴阳炉火，无所不至，妄作妄为，自取凶咎，即太上所谓“不知常，妄作凶”也。 圣训昭昭，世人岂不闻之乎！ 此亦本《道德经》而发明之，示人以返本还源之功。 但将死户为生户，莫执生门号死门。 若会杀机明反覆，始知害里却生恩。 此章言杀机转为生机，即反本之功也。 《阴符经》云：“生者死之根，死者生之根。 恩生于害，害生于恩。 ”盖世人之生死皆由于心，心之生死皆由于物，凡六根门头一切有漏处，悉皆生死岸头也。 何以故？ —切有漏之处，世人莫不依此安身立命，所谓生门也，即皆恩也。 然一切有漏之处，世人莫不从此丧身失命，即所谓死户也，即皆害也。 倘顺而出之，生门转作死门而害生于恩矣。 惟逆而返之，死户转作生户而恩生于害矣。 害生于恩，是生机反为杀机也； 恩生于害，是杀机反为生机也。 所谓杀机反复之妙也。 此章本《阴符》宗旨而发明之。 《道德经》主自然，故直指虚无之体； 《阴清经》主作用，故专提生杀之机。 然生杀之机，即所以归根而复命也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Sixty-Four Quatrains (Seven-Character Regulated Verse)**
*(Corresponding to the Number of Hexagrams)*

From the formless Void the One Qi arises,
From the One Qi then Yin and Yang emerge;
Yin and Yang unite to form the Three Bodies,
The Three Bodies give birth to the flourishing of the myriad things.

This chapter expounds the sequence of the Great Dao’s spontaneous generation. As the *Daode Jing* states: “The Dao gives birth to the One, the One gives birth to the Two, the Two give birth to the Three, the Three give birth to the myriad things.” These few lines encompass all phenomena and embrace the Three Teachings—yet few have grasped their meaning.

The Great Dao is originally without form or substance, utterly boundless as the Great Void, ineffable and unnameable. By force of convention, we call it “Void,” “Spontaneity,” or “the state before qi manifests.” Yet to call it Void is to imply the Real; to call it Nothing is to imply Being; to call it Spontaneity is to imply the fullness of causes and conditions; to speak of it as “before qi appears” is already to acknowledge that the primordial qi has arisen—thus the Dao gives birth to the One. Hence it is said, “From the formless Void the One Qi arises,” which is what Master Zhou meant by “From Non-Ultimate to Supreme Ultimate.”

Once the One Qi divides, within it arise clarity and turbidity, movement and stillness. That which moves, being clear, rises to become Heaven; that which is still, being turbid, congeals to become Earth—thus the One gives birth to the Two. Hence it is said, “From the One Qi then Yin and Yang emerge,” which is what Master Zhou meant by “Yin and Yang divide, and the Two Modes are established.”

Thereafter, the qi of Heaven descends, the qi of Earth ascends; the two qi intermingle, and humans are born within them—thus the Two give birth to the Three. Hence it is said, “Yin and Yang unite to form the Three Bodies,” which is what Master Zhou meant by “The Way of Qian forms the male, the Way of Kun forms the female.”

This single primordial qi pervades and fills all, and once the Three Powers are complete, the ten thousand kinds of beings prosper. Whether sentient or insentient, none fails to fulfill its nature and destiny—thus the Three give birth to the myriad things. Hence it is said, “The Three Bodies give birth to the flourishing of the myriad things,” which is what Master Zhou meant by “The myriad things are born and transform without end.”

This chapter is the patriarchs’ exposition of the *Daode Jing*, elaborated and clarified to serve as the guiding principle for the sixty-four chapters of the middle section—what is called the “forward path of generating humans and things.” If one reverses this process and returns, it becomes the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir.

The myriad things, teeming, each return to their root;
Returning to the root and recovering life—this is enduring.
To know constancy and return to the origin is difficult for people to grasp;
Acting recklessly invites misfortune—this is what all have heard.

This chapter teaches that those who study the Dao must know constancy and return to the origin. The Dao gives birth to the One, the One to the Two, the Two to the Three, the Three to the myriad things. Clearly, the Great Dao is fully present in every thing—how much more so in humans, the most spiritually endowed of beings! Should we not seek to return to the origin and restore the source?

If one can reverse the ordinary course of daily life and seek within, then at the moment when the six sense-roots encounter their objects, one severs the discriminating mind at once. When the discriminating mind ceases, the six senses all come to rest—this is what is meant by “When one root returns to the source, the six roots attain liberation.” From this point, all things—whether sentient or insentient—without exception return to their root, and the prenatal life is restored. When life is restored and the Valley Spirit does not die, it endures eternally—this is what the Most High meant by “The myriad things, teeming, each return to their root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called recovering life.”

The practice of returning to the root and recovering life is within everyone’s capacity, yet people often miss it before their very eyes simply because they do not know constancy. This Dao is utterly plain and without strangeness, utterly bland and without flavor; it does not depart from daily life yet leads directly to the prenatal—this is the Great Constancy. If one can turn the mind around in a single thought, one immediately regains what was originally possessed, and only then does one know that to know constancy is to return to the origin.

Alas! The common people use it daily yet do not recognize it, obscuring their own innate ordinary mind. They often grow weary of constancy and seek novelty, chasing after externals, engaging in all manner of bizarre techniques—yin-yang furnaces and fires, no method left untried. Acting recklessly and deludedly, they bring misfortune upon themselves—this is what the Most High meant by “Not knowing constancy, reckless action brings misfortune.” The sagely teachings are clear—how can people not have heard them?

This too is drawn from the *Daode Jing*, elucidating the practice of returning to the origin and restoring the source.

Turn the gate of death into the gate of life,
Do not cling to the gate of life as the gate of death.
If you grasp the mechanism of killing and understand reversal,
You will know that within harm lies the seed of grace.

This chapter speaks of transforming the mechanism of killing into the mechanism of life—this is the practice of returning to the origin. As the *Yinfu Jing* states: “Life is the root of death, death is the root of life. Grace arises from harm, harm arises from grace.”

The life and death of ordinary people all stem from the mind; the life and death of the mind all stem from things. Wherever the six sense-roots encounter defiled objects, there lies the shore of life and death. Why is this so? Because at every defiled point, people rely on it to establish their being and life—this is what is called the gate of life, and it is all grace. Yet at every defiled point, people also lose their being and life—this is what is called the gate of death, and it is all harm.

If one follows the forward path, the gate of life becomes the gate of death, and harm arises from grace. Only by reversing the path does the gate of death become the gate of life, and grace arise from harm. When harm arises from grace, the mechanism of life becomes the mechanism of killing; when grace arises from harm, the mechanism of killing becomes the mechanism of life—this is the wondrous reversal of the mechanism of killing.

This chapter is drawn from the essential teaching of the *Yinfu Jing*. The *Daode Jing* emphasizes spontaneity, directly pointing to the formless substance; the *Yinfu Jing* emphasizes function, specifically addressing the mechanism of life and death. Yet the mechanism of life and death is precisely what enables one to return to the root and recover life.

chunks.original_text: 祸福由来互倚伏，还如影响相随逐。 若能转此生杀机，反掌之间灾变福。 此章申言生杀之机也。 《感应篇》云：“祸福无门，惟人自召。 ”此太上宝训也，然须知学道人之祸福与世人所谓祸福迥别：盖知常而返本，即自求之福也； 不知常而妄作，即自求之祸也。 岂不互相倚伏，如影之随形，响之应声乎？ 倘能一念回机，则生杀之关立转，一切妄作妄为者，未尝不可知常而返本，其转移之机关只在反掌间。 盖妄即变而为常，即无所不变矣，从此殃可变庆，凶可变吉，灾可变福。 宇宙在手，万化生身，而为造物之所不能杀矣。 祸福倚伏亦本《道德经》，以申言上章杀机反复之意。 要得谷神长不死，须凭玄牝立根基。 真精即返黄金室，一颗明珠永不离。 此章言转两为一，乃金丹立基之功也。 《道德经》云：“谷神不死，是为玄牝。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 ”谷神即本来面目也，谷取其至虚，神取其至灵，至虚至灵之机只在当下。 当下寂然不动，当下感而遂通，其来无首，其去无尾，谷神本自无神生，何有于死！ 仍从此无生中生生不息，而天地万物皆从此出，即是道生（218尾）（221头）一，一生二。 顺而出之以为生机者也。 若要逆而返之以为杀机，妙用须从玄牝立基．坎中真阳为玄，是名有中无，命之寄于身者也； 离中真阴为牝，是名无中有，性之寄于心者也。 两者一合，丹基乃立，谷神自然长存，故曰：“要得谷神长不死，须凭玄牝立根基。 ”玄牝二物会归中黄，先天至精妙合而凝，何啻赤水玄珠得于罔象？ 一得永得，自然须臾不离，故曰：“真精既返黄金屋，一颗明珠永不离。 ”夫真精既返，玄牝之基立矣。 玄珠成象，岂非谷神长不死者乎？ 此转两为一之初基，即转杀为生之妙用也。 先且观天明五贼，次须察地以安民。 民安国富方求战，战罢方能见圣人。 此章言复命之功即金丹作用也。 独修一物即非大道，彼金丹大道何如哉？ 欲修金丹，必须洞晓阴阳，深达造化。 《阴符经》云：“观天之道，执天之行。 ”又云； “天有五贼，见之者昌。 ”五贼者五行，天之所以造化万物，即人之所以自造自化者也。 若不明互生互杀之妙用，怎得成丹？ 故欲执天之行，必先观天之道，内观洞然，才好下手。 身中造化不离方寸地，此地兼摄坎离二用，察之则主立矣。 主立则六根归元，听命天君，是谓“民安”。 三宝内敛，外邪不生，是谓“国富”。 从此坎离交姤，方结金丹，有龙争虎斗之象。 交姤之时，六根大定，意识不行，五贼皆束首受我驱策，阴魔扫迹，有战胜之象。 自此露出本来面目，便是圣胎，而见自己之圣人矣。 以复命而兼了性，与天地合其德，方成大道。 下章遂言战胜之功用。 用将须分左右军，饶他为主我为宾。 劝君临阵休轻敌，恐丧吾家无价珍。 此章申言金丹作用，当明辨宾主以还真也。 战胜而见圣人，金丹之道圆矣。 然方战之时，其功不可不慎。 左属阳右属阴，离为太阳，左也，而实阳中之阴，则居左而反为宾矣； 坎为大阴，右也，而实阴中之阳，则居右而反为主矣。 所谓“用将须分左右军”也。 学者以见性为主，离光是也，奈何中藏阴气，识神尚存，实未得为见性。 一点乾家真性寄体坤中，坎中元炁是也，以其未即来复也，故谓之他，以其为我家故物，故必须让他作主。
chunks.translated_text:
Fortune and misfortune ever intertwine, lying in ambush for one another,
Like shadow following form, echo answering sound.
If one can reverse this mechanism of life and death,
Disaster turns to blessing in the space between a hand’s reversal.

This chapter further expounds the mechanism of life and death.
The *Ganying Pian* states: “Fortune and misfortune have no gate; each is summoned by the self.”
This is the precious teaching of the Most High.
Yet one must know that the fortune and misfortune of those who study the Dao differ entirely from what the world calls fortune and misfortune:
To know the constant and return to the root is to seek one’s own blessing;
Not to know the constant and act recklessly is to seek one’s own misfortune.
Are they not mutually entwined, like shadow following form, echo answering sound?
If one can reverse the mechanism in a single thought,
The pivot of life and death instantly shifts.
All reckless actions and delusions may yet return to knowing the constant and returning to the root.
The moment of transformation lies in the space between a hand’s reversal.
For when delusion is transformed into constancy, there is nothing that cannot be transformed.
From this, calamity may become celebration, ill fortune may become good,
Disaster may become blessing.
The cosmos rests in the palm of one’s hand, the myriad transformations give birth to the body,
And one becomes that which even the Creator cannot destroy.

Fortune and misfortune’s mutual concealment likewise derives from the *Daode Jing*,
Extending the meaning of the previous chapter’s wondrous reversal of the mechanism of killing.

To ensure the Valley Spirit never dies,
One must rely on the Mysterious Female to establish the foundation.
When true essence returns to the Golden Chamber,
A single luminous pearl will never depart.

This chapter speaks of uniting the two as one,
The work of establishing the foundation of the Golden Elixir.
The *Daode Jing* states: “The Valley Spirit does not die; this is called the Mysterious Female.
The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of Heaven and Earth.”
The Valley Spirit is one’s original face:
“Valley” signifies utmost emptiness, “Spirit” signifies utmost numinosity.
The mechanism of utmost emptiness and numinosity resides in the present moment.
In the present moment, still and unmoving;
In the present moment, responsive and unobstructed—
Its coming has no beginning, its going has no end.
The Valley Spirit is originally born from no-spirit; how could it die?
Yet from this birthless state, life endlessly arises,
And the myriad things of Heaven and Earth all emerge from it.
This is the Dao giving birth to the One, the One giving birth to the Two.
To follow and express it is the mechanism of life.
If one wishes to reverse it and return, transforming it into the mechanism of killing,
The wondrous function must begin by establishing the foundation in the Mysterious Female.
True yang within Kan is the Mysterious—what is called “being within non-being,” the life-force lodged in the body;
True yin within Li is the Female—what is called “non-being within being,” the nature lodged in the heart.
When the two unite, the foundation of the Elixir is established,
And the Valley Spirit naturally endures forever.
Thus it is said: “To ensure the Valley Spirit never dies, one must rely on the Mysterious Female to establish the foundation.”
When the Mysterious and the Female converge in the Central Yellow,
The primordial true essence coalesces in wondrous union—
How could it be less than the Dark Pearl of the Red Waters, obtained from the formless?
Once attained, it is forever possessed, naturally never departing for even a moment.
Thus it is said: “When true essence returns to the Golden Chamber, a single luminous pearl will never depart.”
When true essence has returned, the foundation of the Mysterious Female is established.
The Mysterious Pearl takes form—is this not the Valley Spirit that never dies?
This is the initial foundation of uniting the two as one,
The wondrous function of transforming killing into life.

First observe Heaven to illuminate the Five Thieves,
Then examine Earth to pacify the people.
Only when the people are at peace and the state is prosperous may one seek battle;
Only after battle is won may one see the Sage.

This chapter speaks of the work of recovering life as the function of the Golden Elixir.
To cultivate only one thing is not the Great Dao.
How then does the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir proceed?
To refine the Golden Elixir, one must thoroughly understand yin and yang and deeply penetrate the transformations of creation.
The *Yinfu Jing* states: “Observe the Dao of Heaven, grasp the workings of Heaven.”
It also says: “Heaven has Five Thieves; those who see them prosper.”
The Five Thieves are the Five Phases—
What Heaven uses to create and transform the myriad things
Is what humans use to create and transform themselves.
If one does not understand the wondrous function of mutual generation and mutual conquest,
How can one complete the Elixir?
Thus, to grasp the workings of Heaven, one must first observe the Dao of Heaven.
Only when inner observation is thoroughly clear may one begin.
The transformations within the body do not depart from this square inch of earth—
This earth encompasses the dual functions of Kan and Li.
Examine it, and the ruler is established.
When the ruler is established, the six roots return to the origin, heeding the Celestial Lord—this is called “the people at peace.”
When the Three Treasures are inwardly gathered, external evil does not arise—this is called “the state prosperous.”
From this, Kan and Li unite, and the Golden Elixir is formed,
Presenting the image of dragon contending with tiger.
At the moment of union, the six roots are profoundly settled, thought and perception cease,
The Five Thieves all bow their heads and submit to my command,
Yin demons vanish without a trace—this is the image of victorious battle.
From this, the original face is revealed, and this is the Sacred Embryo,
Where one sees one’s own Sage.
Through recovering life and simultaneously completing nature,
One’s virtue merges with that of Heaven and Earth, and the Great Dao is achieved.
The next chapter will speak of the function of victorious battle.

Use generals by distinguishing left and right armies;
Let them be the host while I remain the guest.
I urge you: when facing battle, do not underestimate the enemy,
Lest you lose our priceless treasure.

This chapter further expounds the function of the Golden Elixir,
Emphasizing the need to distinguish host and guest in order to return to the real.
Having won the battle and seen the Sage, the Dao of the Golden Elixir is complete.
Yet at the very moment of battle, one must exercise utmost care.
Left pertains to yang, right to yin.
Li is Great Yang, left, yet within yang it contains yin—thus, though on the left, it is actually the guest.
Kan is Great Yin, right, yet within yin it contains yang—thus, though on the right, it is actually the host.
This is what is meant by “use generals by distinguishing left and right armies.”
The practitioner takes seeing nature as the host—this is the light of Li.
Yet within it lies yin qi, and the consciousness-spirit still remains;
In truth, this is not yet seeing nature.
A single speck of Qian’s true nature resides in Kun’s body—
This is the primordial qi within Kan.
As it has not yet returned, it is called “the other”;
Yet as it is the original treasure of my house, one must let it be the host.
chunks.overlap_context:
hen grace arises from harm, the mechanism of killing becomes the mechanism of life—this is the wondrous reversal of the mechanism of killing.

This chapter is drawn from the essential teaching of the *Yinfu Jing*. The *Daode Jing* emphasizes spontaneity, directly pointing to the formless substance; the *Yinfu Jing* emphasizes function, specifically addressing the mechanism of life and death. Yet the mechanism of life and death is precisely what enables one to return to the root and recover life.

chunks.original_text: 彼即作主，我反为宾矣，主宾互换，颠倒之妙也。 其初先用离中真阴，回光返照，既而取出坎中真阳，反本还源。 识神死尽，真性才得现前，此如大将临阵先擒其王。 真种到手，阴邪自散，但（219尾）（222头）中间进退之宜全仗调停火候，如大敌之不可轻。 倘临炉之时一念妄动，则坎中真阳不可得而取，是“丧却吾家无价珍”也。 可不慎乎！ 此章当与上两章参看，方知宾主颠倒之炒。 更有下劣旁门以此章轻敌、上章战胜等句，附会作采阴邪说，诳惑世人丧身失命，生当受雷霆之诛，死当入无间地狱矣。 异名同出少人知，两者玄玄是要机。 保命全形明损益，紫金丹药最灵奇。 此章申言金丹之要，断在玄牝也。 《道德经》首章云：“故常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其缴”又曰：“此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄。 ”正与玄牝之说互相发明，但世人知之者稀，祖帅特为剖析（221尾）（220头）之。 常无者即玄也、阳也、主也，在人为真性； 常有者即牝也、阴也、宾也，在人为真命。 一分为二，是为异名； 二本乎一，是为同出。 学人能从有入无，返乎先天，是为玄玄之要道矣，故曰：“异名同出少人知，两者玄玄是要机。 ”有无之体虽一，作用却分两般，有为所以保命，当加日益之功； 无为所以了性，当明日损之妙。 损之又损，以至于无，自然形神俱妙，超脱而变化矣，故曰：“保命全形明损益，紫金丹药最灵奇。 ”水火相配合成紫色，即金丹法象，有无交入，性命齐了，岂非玄玄之妙道乎！ 不识阳阳及主宾，知他那个是疏亲？ 房中空闭尾闾穴，误杀阎浮多少人！ 此章言独修一物之非道也。 盖有无同出之谓玄，一阴一阳之谓道，所以金丹之功必须性命全修。 篇中所说阴阳，直接性命而言，只此性命两字，在先天为乾坤，在后天为坎离，此两者有宾有主，有亲有疏，学人宜细辨之。 世人但知以离为性，不知离中之阴，乃后天识神，逐境流转者也。 学人仿佛依通便以此为见性，何异认贼作儿子，未免以宾为主，应疏而反亲矣。 但知以坎为命，不知坎中之阳，即先天乾性，万劫不坏者也。 学人未遇真师，转斥此为外物，何异贫子觅衣珠，未免以主为宾，应亲而反疏矣。 此毫厘千里之差，不可不辨者也。 今世学道者但闻清静之说，便牢闭六窗，灰心静坐。 内不出，外不入，其象为“房中空闭尾闾穴”，即所谓“独修一物是孤阴”者也。 只因不辨宾主亲疏，未明玄玄大道，并其所守之一物亦非矣，误尽世人，可胜道哉！ 昔马祖在南岳，一味坐岳禅，南岳让公启以磨砖岂能作镜，复示以打牛打车之机，始豁然开悟。 会得这则公案，便会得此章关键矣。 玄牝之门世罕知，只将口鼻妄施为。 饶他吐纳经千载，怎得金乌搦兔儿？ 此章申言玄牝妙用，非旁门所知也。 玄牝之与谷神，其体则一，其用则二，名之以一有一无，象之以一乌一兔，张弛阖辟，旋乾转坤，太上所谓玄牝之门，是谓天地根者也。 旁门不知其妙，错认绵绵若存一句，妄以口吐鼻纳为玄牝作用，谬甚矣！ 岂知玄牝二物不过真阴真阳，离中真阴象日中金乌，坎中真阴象月中玉兔。 两者会合，主宾颠倒，自然相擒相制而结金丹。
chunks.translated_text:
When that becomes the host, I instead become the guest—host and guest exchange places, and herein lies the marvel of inversion. At first, one employs the true yin within Li, turning the light back to illuminate; then one draws forth the true yang within Kan, returning to the root and restoring the source. Only when the consciousness-spirit is utterly extinguished does true nature appear before one—this is like a great general entering battle first seizing the enemy’s king. Once the true seed is in hand, yin evil naturally disperses. Yet the proper advance and retreat between these stages (219 end) (222 beginning) depend entirely on regulating the firing times, as one must not treat a great enemy lightly. If, at the moment of tending the furnace, a single deluded thought arises, then the true yang within Kan cannot be obtained—this is “losing the priceless treasure of my house.” How can one not be cautious!

This chapter should be read alongside the two preceding chapters to fully grasp the subtlety of host-guest inversion. There are inferior heterodox schools that distort this chapter’s “treating lightly” and the previous chapter’s “victory in battle,” misapplying them to perverse theories of “harvesting yin,” deceiving the world and causing the loss of body and life. In life, they deserve the thunderbolt’s punishment; in death, they fall into the Avīci Hell.

Different names arise from the same source—few understand this;
Both are profoundly profound, the crucial mechanism.
Preserving life and wholeness clarifies gain and loss;
The Purple Gold Elixir is most wondrously efficacious.

This chapter expounds the essentials of the Golden Elixir, which ultimately lie in the Mysterious Female. The first chapter of the *Daodejing* states: “Thus, by constantly having no desire, one observes its mystery; by constantly having desire, one observes its manifestations.” It also says: “These two emerge together yet have different names—they are both called the Mysterious.” This precisely elucidates the principle of the Mysterious Female. Yet few in the world understand it, so the patriarchs and masters have specially dissected it (221 end) (220 beginning).

“Constantly having no” is the Mysterious, yang, the host—within the person, it is true nature.
“Constantly having” is the Female, yin, the guest—within the person, it is true destiny.
Divided, they are two, hence different names;
Yet both originate from one, hence the same source.
If the practitioner can enter the realm of non-being from being and return to the primordial, this is the essential Dao of the profoundly profound. Thus it is said: “Different names arise from the same source—few understand this; both are profoundly profound, the crucial mechanism.”

Though the substance of being and non-being is one, their functions differ. “Having” serves to preserve destiny, requiring daily accumulation of effort; “non-having” serves to complete nature, requiring daily reduction to subtlety. Reduce and reduce again, until one reaches non-being—naturally, form and spirit become wondrous, transcending and transforming. Thus it is said: “Preserving life and wholeness clarifies gain and loss; the Purple Gold Elixir is most wondrously efficacious.” Water and fire combine to form the color purple—this is the symbol of the Golden Elixir. When being and non-being interpenetrate, nature and destiny are both fulfilled. Is this not the wondrous Dao of the profoundly profound?

Not recognizing yang and yin, host and guest,
How can one know which is distant, which is close?
Sealing the Gate of Life in vain,
How many in Jambudvīpa have been led astray!

This chapter speaks of the error of cultivating only one aspect. For the Mysterious is called “emerging together,” and the Dao is called “one yin, one yang.” Thus, the work of the Golden Elixir must cultivate both nature and destiny. The yin and yang discussed in this text directly pertain to nature and destiny. These two—nature and destiny—are Qian and Kun in the primordial, Kan and Li in the postnatal. Between them are host and guest, close and distant, which the practitioner must carefully discern.

People today know only that Li is nature, unaware that the yin within Li is the postnatal consciousness-spirit, which drifts with circumstances. Practitioners who vaguely follow this path mistake it for seeing nature—how is this different from mistaking a thief for one’s son? They inevitably take the guest as the host, treating the distant as close. They know only that Kan is destiny, unaware that the yang within Kan is the primordial Qian nature, indestructible through endless kalpas. Without meeting a true teacher, practitioners dismiss this as an external thing—how is this different from a poor man seeking his clothing and jewel? They inevitably take the host as the guest, treating the close as distant. This is a difference of a hair’s breadth leading to a thousand *li*—it cannot but be distinguished.

Today’s Dao seekers, upon hearing talk of purity and stillness, tightly seal their six senses and sit in quiescence, neither emitting nor absorbing. This resembles “sealing the Gate of Life in vain,” what is called “cultivating only one thing, a solitary yin.” Because they fail to distinguish host and guest, close and distant, and do not comprehend the great Dao of the profoundly profound, even the one thing they guard is not genuine. They mislead the world—how can this be fully described!

In the past, Master Mazu at Nanyue sat in meditation without cease. Nanyue Huairang admonished him, saying, “Can you grind a brick into a mirror?” and further revealed the mechanism of “striking the ox, striking the cart.” Only then did Mazu suddenly awaken. Grasping this koan is grasping the key to this chapter.

The gate of the Mysterious Female is rarely known in the world;
People vainly apply it to mouth and nose.
Even if one practices breath control for a thousand years,
How can the Golden Crow seize the Jade Rabbit?

This chapter further expounds the wondrous function of the Mysterious Female, unknown to heterodox schools. The Mysterious Female and the Valley Spirit share the same substance but differ in function. They are named as one having, one non-having; symbolized as one crow, one rabbit. Through tension and relaxation, opening and closing, they revolve Qian and turn Kun—this is what Laozi meant by “the gate of the Mysterious Female, called the root of heaven and earth.”

Heterodox schools, misunderstanding the phrase “subtly continuous,” vainly take mouth exhalation and nose inhalation as the function of the Mysterious Female—how grievously mistaken! They do not know that the two things of the Mysterious Female are nothing but true yin and true yang. The true yin within Li is symbolized by the Golden Crow in the sun; the true yang within Kan is symbolized by the Jade Rabbit in the moon. When these two unite, host and guest invert, naturally seizing and restraining each other to congeal the Golden Elixir.

chunks.original_text: 《阴符经》所谓“擒之制在炁”也。 若但以口鼻吐纳为功，纵饶千秋万岁，真阴真阳依然间隔，怎得金乌搦兔之妙用乎？ 此玄牝之门举世所以罕知也。 三才相盗食其时，此是神仙道德机。 万化既安诸虑息，百骸俱理证无为。 此章申言复命之功，从有为以入无为也。 首章原本《道德经》，言“道生一，一生二，二生三”，三才之道备矣。 只此三才，顺之即凡，逆之即圣，学道者窃造化之机而用之，岂难超凡入圣乎？ 《阴符经》云：‘三盗既宜，三才既安。 ”又曰：“食其时，百骸理。 动其机，万化安。 ”盖大丹造化以天为鼎，以地为炉，以日精月华为药物，人居其中运行周天火候，此丹道逆用之三才也。 然有两种作用：以小周天而言，当先取坎中之阳补离中之阴，水火既济，会于中黄，金丹产在炉中矣，其机在侯活子时到，以为采取之功。 以大用天而言，坤反居上，乾反居下，天地反复交在昆仑，还丹收归鼎内矣，其机在候正子时到，以为锻炼之准。 两种作用内外交通，始得参合三才，结而成丹，无非以真意和合身心，使元精、元炁妙合而凝，谷神自然长存。 人但知为神仙妙诀，不知此乃修德凝道中一段自然机用，即归根复命之要道也。 锻炼之后身心大定，天君坐镇中央，寂然不动，而五官四肢三百六十骨节八万四千毛孔，元炁周流，一切归命中黄正位。 譬如北辰居所，而众星自拱，又如阳回寒谷，大地皆春。 可谓各正性命而保合太和矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Classic of Uniting Yin and Yang* speaks of "seizing and restraining through qi." If one merely takes mouth exhalation and nose inhalation as the practice, even after a thousand autumns and ten thousand years, true yin and true yang will remain separated—how could one attain the wondrous function of the Golden Crow seizing the Jade Rabbit? This is why the gate of the Mysterious Female is so rarely known in the world.

The three powers mutually steal and consume in their time—this is the mechanism of immortals' virtue and power. When the myriad transformations are at peace and all concerns cease, the hundred bones are all ordered, and non-doing is realized. This chapter expounds further on the work of returning to life, moving from doing to non-doing.

The first chapter originally derives from the *Dao De Jing*, speaking of "the Dao giving birth to the One, the One giving birth to the Two, the Two giving birth to the Three"—thus the Way of the three powers is complete. These three powers, when followed, make one ordinary; when reversed, make one sagely. Those who study the Dao steal the mechanism of creation and employ it—how could it be difficult to transcend the ordinary and enter sageliness?

The *Classic of Uniting Yin and Yang* states: "When the three thieves are fitting, the three powers are at peace." It also says: "Consume in their time, and the hundred bones are ordered. Move their mechanism, and the myriad transformations are at peace." The great elixir’s creation takes heaven as the crucible, earth as the furnace, the essence of the sun and the radiance of the moon as medicinal substances. The human, residing within, circulates the fire times of the celestial cycle—this is the reversal of the three powers in the elixir’s Way.

Yet there are two kinds of function: Regarding the minor celestial cycle, one must first extract the yang within Kan to replenish the yin within Li. When water and fire are conjoined, meeting at the central yellow, the golden elixir is produced within the furnace. Its mechanism lies in awaiting the arrival of the living zi hour for the work of gathering.

Regarding the great function of heaven, Kun is inverted above, Qian inverted below; heaven and earth are overturned and exchanged at Kunlun, and the returned elixir is gathered into the crucible. Its mechanism lies in awaiting the arrival of the proper zi hour as the standard for refinement.

When these two functions communicate internally and externally, the three powers are then united to congeal the elixir—all through the true intention harmonizing body and mind, causing original essence and original qi to wondrously unite and coagulate. The Valley Spirit naturally abides forever.

People know this as the immortals’ wondrous technique, yet they do not realize it is but a natural mechanism within the cultivation of virtue and the congealing of the Dao—precisely the essential path of returning to the root and reviving life. After refinement, body and mind are greatly settled; the Heavenly Lord sits enthroned at the center, utterly still. The five officials, four limbs, three hundred sixty joints, and eighty-four thousand pores—original qi circulates through them all, everything returning to the central yellow’s proper position.

It is like the North Star residing in its place while the host of stars naturally encircle it, or like yang returning to the cold valley, the great earth all spring. This may be called each rectifying its nature and life, preserving and uniting Great Harmony.

chunks.original_text: 岂非万化既安，诸虑尽息，百骸俱理，而得证无为者乎？ 此章言会三归一，从有为以入无为，正与首章相应。 盖即《阴符》之作用，契《道德》之自然，摄用归体，以了命而兼了性者也。 《阴符》宝字愈三百，《道德》灵文止五千。 今古上仙无限数，尽于此处达真诠。 此章标两经宗旨，以示大道之渊源也。 大道非师不传，非经不印，经者千圣相传之心印。 然三洞真经部啻数千卷，独推《阴符》、《道德》两经开山作祖者，以其道合天人，为穷理尽性至命之真诠耳。 然两经宗旨同而不同，异而不异：《道德》直指自然之本体，其道从无入有，其机主顺； 《阴符经》专提归根之作用，其道从有入无，其机主逆。 即如篇中所引虚无一炁，顺也； 继以知常返本，则逆矣。 同出异名，顺也，继以察地安民，则逆矣。 至于谷神之妙，先从玄牝立基，则顺而未始不逆； 相盗之机。 究竟无为得证，则逆而未常不顺。 此又见《道德》、《阴符》有无不二，性命同源之妙也。 然两经文字极其简奥，《阴符》字仅三百，《道德》文止五千，自古上仙大圣，皆从得大受用。 后来着书立说者终不能出其范围，诚哉！ 其为穷理尽性至命之真诠也已。 契论经歌讲至真，不将火候着于文。 要知口诀通玄处，须共神仙仔细论。 此章言火候之秘必假师传也。 《阴符》、《道德》两经，垂示真诠，为万古学道者作指南针。 然其书乃直指归根复命至真之要道，尚未落丹经诸名相也。 至汉魏伯阳真人始准易象作《参同契》．建立鼎炉、药物、火候诸名相。 大约以乾坤为鼎炉，以坎离为药物，以余六十卦为周天火候，意玄而语奥，遂称丹经鼻祖。 从此接踵而起者，有论有经有歌，横说竖说，无非以寓言发明至真之理。 其所陈者，卦爻铢两； 所用者，年月日时。 此特火候之名相耳。 至真之诀，虽隐然在中，却又引而不发，其中玄妙，须得圣师口口相授，片言指破天机，则纸上陈言总是源头活水，紫清真人所谓“都来半句，贯串万卷丹经”是也。 不则双眼黑漆漆地，纵有解会，一似镜里观花，水中提月，从何处着眼？ 从何处下手哉？
chunks.translated_text:
Is this not the state where the myriad transformations are at peace, all cares extinguished, the hundred bones all ordered, and the attainment of non-doing realized? This chapter speaks of the convergence of the Three into the One, the passage from doing into non-doing—precisely corresponding to the opening chapter.

Here lies the application of the *Yinfu*, the accord with the spontaneity of the *Daode*; gathering function into substance, thereby completing life and simultaneously completing nature. The *Yinfu* treasures its three hundred characters, the *Daode*’s numinous text spans five thousand. Countless immortals of past and present have all, through this very point, grasped the true essence.

This chapter marks the cardinal principles of the two scriptures, revealing the profound origins of the Great Dao. The Great Dao is not transmitted without a master, nor authenticated without scripture—scripture being the heart-seal passed down by a thousand sages. Yet among the thousands of volumes in the Three Caverns’ true scriptures, only the *Yinfu* and *Daode* are hailed as the founding ancestors, for their Dao unites Heaven and humanity, serving as the true essence of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining life.

Yet the two scriptures share the same principle while differing, differ yet remain the same: the *Daode* directly points to the natural original substance, its Dao proceeding from non-being into being, its mechanism governed by compliance. The *Yinfu Jing* specifically elevates the function of returning to the root, its Dao proceeding from being into non-being, its mechanism governed by reversal. As in the passage cited—“the single qi of emptiness and nothingness” is compliance; yet following it with “knowing constancy and returning to the root” is reversal. “The same in origin yet different in name” is compliance; yet following it with “examining earth and pacifying the people” is reversal. As for the wondrousness of the Valley Spirit, first establishing the foundation in the Mysterious Female is compliance yet never without reversal; the mechanism of mutual theft. Ultimately, the attainment of non-doing is reversal yet never without compliance. Here again we see the non-duality of being and non-being in the *Daode* and *Yinfu*, the wondrous unity of nature and life.

Yet the texts of the two scriptures are exceedingly terse and profound—the *Yinfu*’s characters barely three hundred, the *Daode*’s text only five thousand—yet from ancient times, immortals and great sages have all derived great benefit from them. Later authors, in their writings and discourses, have never transcended their scope. Truly, they are the true essence of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining life!

The songs and discourses on the true scriptures never commit the fire-phases to writing. To know the oral secrets that penetrate the mysterious, one must discuss them in detail with the immortals. This chapter speaks of the necessity of a master’s transmission for the secrets of the fire-phases.

The *Yinfu* and *Daode* scriptures have bequeathed the true essence, serving as the compass for all who study the Dao across the ages. Yet these books directly point to the essential path of returning to the root and reviving life, without yet employing the terminology of alchemical scriptures. It was not until the Han dynasty’s Wei Boyang that, basing his work on the *Yijing*’s imagery, he composed the *Cantong Qi*, establishing terms such as the tripod and furnace, the medicine, and the fire-phases. Generally, he took Qian and Kun as the tripod and furnace, Kan and Li as the medicine, and the remaining sixty hexagrams as the fire-phases of the celestial cycle. His meaning was profound, his language abstruse, and thus it became known as the ancestor of alchemical scriptures.

From then on, successors arose in succession, producing treatises, scriptures, and songs, expounding horizontally and vertically—all employing allegory to elucidate the ultimate truth. What they set forth were the hexagrams and lines, the grains and ounces; what they employed were the years, months, days, and hours. These are merely the nominal forms of the fire-phases. The true oral secrets, though implicitly present, remain unspoken, their mysteries requiring a sage-master’s direct transmission—a single phrase to unlock the celestial mechanism—whereupon the written words on the page become the living source, as the Purple Clarity Perfected One said: “All comes down to half a phrase, threading through ten thousand volumes of alchemical scriptures.”

Without this, one’s eyes remain pitch-black, and even with understanding, it is like gazing at flowers in a mirror or grasping the moon in water—where to fix one’s gaze? Where to begin?

chunks.original_text: 饶君聪慧过颜闵，不遇师传莫强猜。 只为丹经无口诀，教君何处结灵胎？ 此章言金丹大道，非师传不明也。 上章言口诀必待师传，信矣。 或疑世有聪慧绝人者，似可无待于师，殊不知性由自悟，命假师传，自古到今，未有无师而得证尽性至命之大道者。 所以黄帝拜访于崆峒，孔子特询乎柱下，此两圣者岂非慧过颜闵者哉？ 彼其求师问道何其勤勤，正以道妙不可强猜耳。 即如《阴符》、《道德》两经所言知常返本、察地观天底道理，只在眼前，然未遇真师，无异水中捉月，镜里观花，令人何处下手？ 又况后来丹经所述药物、火候之秘，曲譬广喻，名相离奇，有不目眩神惊者乎？ 明之尚且不易，矧能如法行持以结圣胎乎？ 学道者当急访真师以求真决，毋得蹉跎岁月也。 然则丹经竞无用乎，曰真诀原只在丹经中，正如僧繇画龙一般，未经点眼尚是壁间之龙，一朝点出便破壁而飞去矣。 点眼之妙存乎真师。 梦谒西华到九天，真人授我指玄篇。 其中简要无多语，只要教人炼汞铅。 此章言真师口诀只在汞铅二物也。 汞本无质，喻妙有中真空； 铅却有形，喻真空中妙有。 妙有中真空即先天祖性，乾是也； 真空中妙有即先天元命，坤是也。 在后天性寄于心、故乾破为离，离之中虚者乃真汞也； 命寄于身，故坤实成坎，坎之中实者乃真铅也。 学道者能取坎中之阳，点离中之阴，才复还先天乾体，此炼后天两物以成金丹也。 到得两物合体化作先天一炁，始号真铅，却又只是一物，此名外药。 复加采取而烹炼之，一点落在黄庭，凝结圣胎，此名内药。 更须抽铅添汞，炼之又炼，返于虚无，始称真汞。 铅尽汞干才得超凡入圣，此炼先天—炁以成大还丹也。 大抵以真铅喻身，真汞喻心，炼真铅所以了命，炼真汞所以了性。 性命齐了，大道毕矣。 岂非至简至易之真诠乎！ 我紫阳张祖当年于西蜀成都青城山面遇海蟾刘祖，拜授金丹秘诀，后因误传获谴，隐名着书，遂并其师承而隐之。 篇中性命微言皆从刘祖口授，而付之一梦，其意良深。 以西蜀为西华，以真授为梦授，以“指玄”二字隐跃《悟真》，无非活句，若作实法会，即是痴人说梦矣。 用铅不得用凡铅，用了真铅也弃捐； 此是用铅真妙诀，用铅不用是诚言。 此章揭示真铅之妙用也。 上章铅汞对举，而此单举真铅者，点出金丹大药，令人知下手处也。 盖真铅是先天一炁，从虚无中来者，凡铅乃凡精凡气也。 然对坎离二物而言，身中凡精凡气总属凡铅； 对先天一炁而言，则离中至阴之精、坎中至阳之炁又属凡铅矣。 直到二物会合，产出一点真种，才算得真铅。 真铅即金丹也，即所谓先天一炁从虚无中来者。 学者既识得此真种，采取而锻炼之，是名金液还丹。 更加温养乳哺之功，损之又损，以至虚无，消尽后天阴滓，浑然一片，先天法身圆明，与太空同体，是并其真铅而弃捐之矣，况凡铅乎？ 虽不用铅，其初却又用铅； 虽似用铅，究竟又不用铅。
chunks.translated_text:
Though your wisdom surpasses Yan and Min’s,
Without a master’s transmission, do not force conjecture.
For the alchemical scriptures lack the oral secrets—
Where then can you conceive the numinous embryo?

This chapter speaks of the great Way of the Golden Elixir:
without a master’s transmission, it cannot be understood.
The preceding chapter affirmed that the oral secrets must await a master’s transmission—how true this is!
Some may doubt that those of extraordinary intelligence could do without a master,
yet while nature is realized through self-awakening, life depends on a master’s transmission.
From ancient times to the present, none have ever attained the great Way of exhausting nature and fulfilling life without a master.
Thus the Yellow Emperor sought instruction at Kongtong,
and Confucius inquired of the Keeper beneath the Pillar—
were these two sages not wiser than Yan and Min?
Yet how earnestly they sought masters and questioned the Dao!
Precisely because the Dao’s wonders cannot be forced by guesswork.
Even in the *Yinfu* and *Daode* classics, the principles of knowing constancy and returning to the root, of examining earth and observing heaven, lie right before one’s eyes—
yet without encountering a true master, it is no different from grasping the moon in water or gazing at flowers in a mirror.
Where can one begin?
Moreover, the later alchemical scriptures describe the secrets of medicinal substances and fire-phases in elaborate metaphors and far-flung analogies, with names and forms so strange—
who would not be dazzled and astonished?
If even understanding is difficult,
how much more so to practice correctly and conceive the sacred embryo?
Those who study the Dao must urgently seek a true master to obtain the true secrets,
lest they waste their years in vain.

But then, are the alchemical scriptures entirely useless?
The true secrets originally reside within them—
just as when Zeng You painted a dragon:
before the eyes were dotted, it remained a dragon on the wall,
but once the eyes were added, it broke through the wall and flew away.
The marvel of dotting the eyes lies with the true master.

In a dream I met the Western Flower and ascended to the Nine Heavens,
where the Perfected One bestowed upon me the *Zhixuan* chapter.
Its essentials are few in words,
only teaching one to refine mercury and lead.

This chapter speaks of the true master’s oral secrets, which lie solely in the two substances: mercury and lead.
Mercury, being without form, symbolizes true emptiness within wondrous existence;
lead, having form, symbolizes wondrous existence within true emptiness.
True emptiness within wondrous existence is the primordial ancestral nature—this is Qian.
Wondrous existence within true emptiness is the primordial original life—this is Kun.
In the postnatal realm, nature resides in the heart, so Qian is broken into Li,
and the emptiness at Li’s center is true mercury.
Life resides in the body, so Kun is solidified into Kan,
and the fullness at Kan’s center is true lead.
If the Dao student can extract the yang from Kan and infuse the yin in Li,
they restore the primordial Qian,
thus refining the two postnatal substances to form the Golden Elixir.
Only when the two substances merge and transform into the primordial qi
is it called true lead—yet it is still but one substance, known as the outer medicine.
Refining it further and gathering it,
a single point descends into the Yellow Court, congealing into the sacred embryo—
this is the inner medicine.
One must then draw out the lead and replenish the mercury, refining again and again,
returning to emptiness and nothingness—
only then is it called true mercury.
When the lead is exhausted and the mercury dried,
one transcends the mundane and enters sagehood—
this is refining the primordial qi to achieve the Great Return Elixir.

In general, true lead symbolizes the body, and true mercury the heart.
Refining true lead fulfills life; refining true mercury fulfills nature.
When both nature and life are fulfilled, the great Dao is complete.
Is this not the most simple and easy of true teachings?

In those years, my ancestor Zhang Ziyang encountered Master Liu Haichan at Mount Qingcheng in Chengdu, Sichuan,
and received the secret oral instructions of the Golden Elixir.
Later, due to a transmission error, he incurred censure,
so he concealed his name and wrote books, even obscuring his lineage.
The subtle words on nature and life in his works all came from Master Liu’s oral teachings,
yet he presented them as a dream—his meaning runs deep.
Taking Sichuan as the Western Flower, true transmission as dream transmission,
and the two characters *zhixuan* (指玄) as an allusion to the *Wuzhen* (悟真),
all are living phrases—
to take them as literal methods is to be a fool speaking of dreams.

Use lead, yet do not use common lead;
once true lead is used, it too is discarded.
This is the true marvel of using lead—
“Use lead yet do not use it” is the sincere teaching.

This chapter reveals the marvelous function of true lead.
The preceding chapter presented lead and mercury together,
but here true lead is singled out to point out the great medicine of the Golden Elixir,
showing where to begin.
True lead is the primordial qi that arises from emptiness and nothingness,
while common lead is merely common essence and common qi.
Yet in relation to the two substances Kan and Li,
the common essence and qi within the body all belong to common lead;
in relation to the primordial qi,
the utmost yin essence in Li and the utmost yang qi in Kan are also common lead.
Only when the two substances unite and produce a single true seed
is it called true lead.
True lead is the Golden Elixir—
the so-called primordial qi that arises from emptiness and nothingness.
Once the student recognizes this true seed and gathers and refines it,
it is called the Golden Liquid Return Elixir.
With further nurturing and nourishing,
reducing and reducing again until reaching emptiness and nothingness,
the postnatal yin dregs are entirely dissolved,
and the primordial Dharma-body becomes perfectly luminous, one with the great void—
thus even true lead is discarded,
let alone common lead.
Though one does not use lead, one initially must use it;
though it seems one uses lead, ultimately one does not use it.

chunks.original_text: 从有为而入无为，即了命而兼了性。 岂非西华所授之妙诀，即从上诸祖之心印乎？ 古诗云：“用铅不用铅，须向铅中作，及至用铅时，用铅还是错。 ”正见用而不用，不用而用，颠倒倒颠之妙。 凡篇中所云真铅皆与此同看。 竹破须将竹补宜，抱鸡当用卵为之。 万般非类徒劳力，争似真铅合圣机。 此章申言真铅为还丹真种也。 真铅固是先天一炁，不落形质，然必须后天同类之物有以致之。 盖后天不得先天无以变化，先天不得后天无以招摄。 离中至阴之精，坎中至阳之炁，虽属后天，即真铅之所自出也。 两者一合，真铅自生。 此中招摄之妙，有如用竹补竹，用卵抱鸡，自然无中生有，返本还源。 后天形质才得真铅点化，自然超凡而入圣矣。 除却坎离二用，总属非类，何以致真铅而合圣机哉？ 未炼还丹莫隐山，山中前后尽非铅。 此般至宝家家有，自是时人识不全。 此章言真铅作用，不可偏于守静也。 坎离两物会合方称真铅，真铅即金丹也。 既得真铅，再加向上工夫，采取而锻炼之，方称金液还丹。 还丹既得，更加九年面壁之功，宣到—尘不染，万境皆空，才合隐山法象。 还丹未就，且当求之于尘市可也。 若便灰心冥目，关闭六窗，隔绝前后，则外药之用从何而生？ 故曰：“未炼还丹莫隐山，山中前后尽非铅。 ”真铅之体产自先天，虽则人人具足，然非真师点破，识之甚难。 非金石凡药，非彼家邪秽，并非身中精气。 倘离此数者息心内守，又未免独修一物，落断灭种性边见。 如入深山而求铅，必不可得矣。 可惜至宝不遇真师点破，遂致人人觌面蹉过，故曰：“此般至宝家家有，自是时人识不全。 ”此章言复命之功，不专守静隐山之象，甚奇，当与居尘市闭尾闾两首参看，方知其奥。 虚心实腹义惧深，只为虚心要识心。 不若炼铅先实腹，且教守取满堂金。 此章言立命之功先于了性也。 《道德经》云； “虚其心，实其腹。 ”此句意义深远，举世莫能窥测。 盖实腹是有为之功，所以了命； 虚心是无为之妙，所以了性。 心体本同太虚，空空洞洞，万象俱涵，一物不着，人能一念回机，直下识取本来面目，则心不期虚而自虚矣。 此乃高上之士先了性而后了命者，所谓修上一关盖下二关也。 中下之流到此便无站脚处，不若先做炼铅工夫以实其腹，命根即固，方可徐徐了性。 然真铅亦未易炼也。 凡夫心扰欲牵，刻刻向外驰求，耗散本来，如金玉满堂莫之能守。 何以守之？ 只索收视返听，绝利一源以招致先天一炁而已。 六根大定，返乎先天，是为真铅。 真铅即得，命基永固，而腹先实矣，炼之又炼，从有为入无为，直到性地圆明而心亦虚矣。 虚心实腹二义虽有了性了命之殊，而末常不同归，可见圣意虽深远难测，而未常不可测也。 以上数章俱发明先天真铅之妙，欲炼真铅必须从取坎填离起手，故下章紧接坎离二物。 日居离位反为女，坎配蟾宫却是男； 不会此中颠倒意，休将管见事高谈。 此章言坎离颠倒之妙，乃真铅所自出也。 金丹之要只在真铅，真铅之用不出坎离二物。 离为日，日乃太阳真火，是先天乾父法象，不知乾破为离，乾父反为中女矣； 坎为月，月乃太阴真水，是先天坤母法象，不知坤实为坎，坤母反为中男矣。
chunks.translated_text:
From the realm of effort one enters the realm of effortlessness—
thus perfecting destiny while simultaneously perfecting nature.
Is this not the wondrous secret transmitted by Western Florescence,
the very mind-seal of all the patriarchs from time immemorial?
An ancient poem says:
*"Use lead yet do not use lead—
one must work within the lead itself.
But when it comes to using lead,
using lead is still a mistake."*
Here lies the marvel of using yet not using,
not using yet using—
the wondrous inversion of inversion.
All references to true lead in these passages should be understood in this light.
When bamboo is broken, one must use bamboo to mend it;
to hatch a chick, one must use an egg.
All other methods are vain labor—
how could they compare to true lead uniting with the sage’s mechanism?

This chapter further expounds that true lead is the true seed of the Return Elixir.
True lead is indeed the primordial qi, unconfined by form or substance,
yet it must be drawn forth by a postnatal substance of the same kind.
For without the postnatal, the primordial has nothing to transform;
without the primordial, the postnatal has nothing to summon.
The utmost yin essence in Li and the utmost yang qi in Kan,
though belonging to the postnatal,
are precisely the source from which true lead arises.
When these two unite, true lead is spontaneously born.
The marvel of this summoning lies in using bamboo to mend bamboo,
using an egg to hatch a chick—
naturally generating being from non-being,
returning to the root and restoring the source.
Once the postnatal form and substance receive the transmutation of true lead,
one naturally transcends the mundane and enters sagehood.

Apart from the dual function of Kan and Li,
all else is of a different kind—
how could it summon true lead and unite with the sage’s mechanism?

*"Do not retreat to the mountains before refining the Return Elixir—
in the mountains, before and after, all is not lead."*
This supreme treasure exists in every household,
yet people of this age fail to recognize it fully.

This chapter speaks of the function of true lead,
warning against an overemphasis on quiescent cultivation.
Only when the two substances of Kan and Li unite is it called true lead—
true lead is the Golden Elixir.
Having obtained true lead, one must further apply the work of ascent,
gathering and refining it,
only then is it called the Golden Liquid Return Elixir.
Once the Return Elixir is attained,
one must add the nine-year effort of wall-facing,
achieving a state of spotless purity where all realms are empty,
only then does it accord with the mountain-retreating symbolism.
Before the Return Elixir is accomplished,
one should seek it amidst the dust of the marketplace.
If one prematurely dulls the mind and shuts the eyes,
sealing off the six senses and severing past and future,
how can the function of the external medicine arise?
Thus it is said:
*"Do not retreat to the mountains before refining the Return Elixir—
in the mountains, before and after, all is not lead."*

The essence of true lead is born of the primordial,
and though it is possessed by all,
without a true teacher’s revelation, it is exceedingly difficult to recognize.
It is neither mineral nor common medicine,
nor the impure and deviant,
nor the essence and qi within the body.
If one abandons these and turns inward in quiescent cultivation,
one risks falling into the error of solitary cultivation,
adhering to the annihilationist view of extinguishing the seed-nature.
Seeking lead in the depths of the mountains,
one will surely fail to obtain it.
Alas, this supreme treasure, unrecognized by a true teacher,
is thus overlooked by all, though it lies before their very eyes.
Hence it is said:
*"This supreme treasure exists in every household,
yet people of this age fail to recognize it fully."*

This chapter on the work of restoring destiny
does not advocate solely for quiescent retreat in the mountains—
it is most extraordinary.
One should compare it with the two chapters on dwelling in the marketplace
and sealing the tailbone to grasp its profundity.

*"Empty the heart and fill the belly—
the meaning is profound,
for the heart must be emptied to recognize the heart.
Better to first refine lead and fill the belly,
then guard the hall full of gold."*

This chapter speaks of establishing destiny before perfecting nature.
The *Dao De Jing* says:
*"Empty the heart, fill the belly."*
This phrase holds boundless meaning,
yet the world cannot fathom it.
Filling the belly is the work of effort, for perfecting destiny;
emptying the heart is the marvel of effortlessness, for perfecting nature.
The heart’s essence is originally one with the great void—
vast and empty, containing all phenomena,
yet clinging to nothing.
If one can turn the mind in a single thought
and directly recognize the original face,
then the heart, without seeking emptiness, becomes empty of itself.
This is the path of the loftiest adepts,
who first perfect nature before perfecting destiny—
what is called "cultivating the upper gate to seal the lower two."
For those of middling and lesser capacity,
this path offers no foothold.
Better to first undertake the work of refining lead to fill the belly,
thus securing the root of destiny,
before gradually perfecting nature.
Yet true lead is not easily refined.
The ordinary person’s heart is disturbed by desires,
constantly chasing externals,
dissipating the original endowment—
like a hall full of gold and jade that cannot be guarded.
How to guard it?
One must withdraw the gaze and reverse the hearing,
cutting off the source of profit to summon the primordial qi.
When the six roots are greatly stabilized and one returns to the primordial,
this is true lead.
Once true lead is obtained, the foundation of destiny is eternally secure,
and the belly is first filled.
Refining it further and further,
moving from effort to effortlessness,
one ultimately reaches the radiant clarity of the nature-ground,
and the heart, too, becomes empty.
Though the two meanings of emptying the heart and filling the belly
differ in perfecting nature and perfecting destiny,
they ultimately converge.
Thus, though the sage’s intent is profound and difficult to fathom,
it is not unfathomable.

The preceding chapters all elucidate the marvel of primordial true lead.
To refine true lead, one must begin with drawing from Kan to fill Li.
Thus, the next chapter closely follows with the two substances of Kan and Li.

*"The sun dwells in the Li position yet becomes the maiden;
the moon pairs with the toad palace yet becomes the youth.
If one does not grasp this inverted meaning,
do not presumptuously discourse on lofty matters."*

This chapter speaks of the marvelous inversion of Kan and Li,
from which true lead arises.
The essential point of the Golden Elixir lies solely in true lead;
the function of true lead does not extend beyond the two substances of Kan and Li.
Li is the sun, the true fire of utmost yang—
the primordial Qian father’s symbol.
Yet one does not know that Qian is broken to become Li,
and the Qian father becomes the central maiden.
Kan is the moon, the true water of utmost yin—
the primordial Kun mother’s symbol.
Yet one does not know that Kun is filled to become Kan,
and the Kun mother becomes the central youth.

chunks.original_text: 此先天转作后天颠倒之妙也，若能再一颠倒，则离中一阴复归于坤，坎中一阳复归于乾。 亲上亲下，各从其类，后天不又转作先天乎？ 不会此中颠倒之妙而高谈阔论，何异以管窥天，可发一笑。 世人不知道而妄谈道，祖师所以三叹也。 颠倒之妙详见下章。 震龙汞出自离乡，兑虎金生在坎方， 二物总因儿产母，五行全要入中央。 此章言金木之用总归真土也。 丹道以水火为体，坎离是也； 以金木为用，震兑是也。 究竟四象不离二体，后天震居东，即先天离位，所以震中木汞出自南方离火，所谓龙从火里出也； 后天兑居正西，即先天坎位，所以兑中铅金生自北方坎水，所谓虎向水中生也。 火反生木，水转生金，母子颠倒。 故曰“二物总因儿产母”。 东三南二北一西四，会归中黄真土，始成金丹。 故曰“五行全要入中央”。 上章言水火以立体，此章言金木以致用，合之而四象全矣，其要只在中土。 离坎若还无戊己，虽含四象不成丹。 只缘彼此怀真土，遂使金丹有返还。 此章言真土之功，能和合四象而成金丹也。 真土者，真意之别名也。 当其寂然不动，是为己土； 及其感而遂通，是为戊土。 其体则一，其用则二。 体在中宫，用寄坎离。 盖坎中纳戊，离中纳己，若非流戊就已，则金木水火各散而不能成丹。 惟真意一到，才能调和身心，摄伏魂魄，四象合作一家，返本还源只在刹那间，而金丹大药结矣。 真土之功不亦大乎！ 火生于木本藏锋，不会钻研莫强攻。 祸发总因斯害己，要须制伏觅金公。 此章言金木相制之功也。 上章说四象归于戊己，是总言金丹妙用，此又分而言之。 木体喻人生而静之性，木中生火喻感物而动之情。 情藏于性，本自寂然，只因六根门头触境逢缘，处处粘着，引起业识，倏生忿欲。 忿欲一起，即能焚却太和元炁。 犹之火藏于木，本自宴然，只因钻木发火，烽烟一发即能烧却本身矣，所谓“祸发必克而害己”也。 此岂可以私智钻研，强为攻治乎？ 必欲制伏，非水中之金不可。 盖木性轻浮，金性镇重，木汞本流走不定，一见金铅自然受制，六根门头处处勒转，才得转识成智，返情为性，从此定水湛若，慧火长明。 忿不惩而自惩，欲不窒而自窒，而寂然不动矣。 金既制木，水即制火，岂复有祸发必克之患乎？ 此即金丹颠倒之妙也。 金公本是东家子，送在西邻寄体生。 认得唤来归舍养，配将姹女结亲情。 此章言以铅入汞也。 先天羲易本离东而坎西，故取东家西邻之象。 金公是坎中真阳，因乾破成离而陷坤官以成坎者，岂不犹东家子而寄养西邻者乎？ 真阳虽然流落在外，面目依稀，急须认取。 倘能以真意为媒，取出坎中真阳，配合离中真阴，二物归于土釜，金情木性自然两相和协，金丹得就矣，岂不犹配姹女而生婴儿者耶？ 此亦颠倒之妙也。 姹女游行各有方，前行须短后须长， 归来却入黄婆舍，嫁个金公作老郎。 此章言以汞投铅也。 离中流珠喻后天之心，其性喜走，出入无时，流连前境，未肯退藏，若女子之好游。 然本自一精，明分为六，和合六根六尘，随其所向而昼夜奔驰，何时得休歇乎？ 不知涉境则览物招愆，退藏斯安身得地。 譬如女子在母家之日宜短，在夫家之日宜长，自有一定安身立命底所在。
chunks.translated_text:
This is the marvelous inversion of the primordial turning into the postnatal. If one can invert it once more, then the single yin within Li returns to Kun, and the single yang within Kan returns to Qian. Each seeks its kin above and below, each follows its kind—does not the postnatal then revert to the primordial? Failing to grasp this marvelous inversion while discoursing grandly is no different from peering at the heavens through a tube—worthy of a laugh. Those in the world who do not understand the Dao yet recklessly expound upon it are why the ancestral masters sighed thrice. The marvel of inversion is detailed in the next chapter.

The dragon’s mercury emerges from the Li homeland,
the tiger’s metal is born in the Kan quarter.
These two things arise only when the child gives birth to the mother;
the five phases all must enter the center.
This chapter speaks of the functions of metal and wood, which ultimately return to true earth. In the Dao of the Elixir, water and fire serve as the body—these are Kan and Li; metal and wood serve as the function—these are Zhen and Dui. In the end, the four images do not depart from the two bodies. In the postnatal, Zhen resides in the east, which is the Li position of the primordial, so the wood-mercury within Zhen emerges from the southern Li fire—this is what is meant by "the dragon emerges from within fire." In the postnatal, Dui resides in the west, which is the Kan position of the primordial, so the metal-lead within Dui is born from the northern Kan water—this is what is meant by "the tiger is born from within water." Fire, in reverse, gives birth to wood; water, in turn, gives birth to metal—mother and child are inverted. Thus it is said, "These two things arise only when the child gives birth to the mother." East three, south two, north one, west four—all converge in the central yellow true earth, and only then is the Golden Elixir formed. Thus it is said, "The five phases all must enter the center."

The previous chapter spoke of water and fire to establish the body; this chapter speaks of metal and wood to achieve function. Together, the four images are complete, and their essential point lies solely in the central earth. If Li and Kan lack Wu and Ji, though they contain the four images, the Elixir will not form. It is only because each holds true earth that the Golden Elixir can return and revert. This chapter speaks of the power of true earth, which harmonizes the four images to form the Golden Elixir. True earth is another name for true intent. When it is quiescent and unmoving, it is called Ji earth; when it responds and connects, it is called Wu earth. Its essence is one, but its functions are two. Its body resides in the central palace, and its function is lodged in Kan and Li. Kan contains Wu, and Li contains Ji. If Wu does not flow to Ji, then metal, wood, water, and fire scatter and cannot form the Elixir. Only when true intent arrives can it harmonize body and mind, subdue the hun and po, and unite the four images into one household. Returning to the source occurs in an instant, and the great medicine of the Golden Elixir is congealed. Is not the power of true earth great indeed!

Fire is born from wood, but its edge is concealed;
without understanding drilling and refining, do not forcefully attack.
Disaster arises precisely from this harm to oneself—
one must seek to subdue it with the Golden Elder.
This chapter speaks of the power of metal and wood restraining each other. The previous chapter discussed the four images returning to Wu and Ji, which is a general explanation of the marvelous function of the Golden Elixir; here, it is discussed in detail. The body of wood is likened to the inherently quiescent nature of human life; the fire born within wood is likened to the emotions that arise when encountering things. Emotions are concealed within nature, originally quiescent, but because the six roots encounter boundaries and conditions at every turn, clinging and attaching everywhere, they stir karmic consciousness and suddenly give rise to anger and desire. Once anger and desire arise, they can burn away the primordial qi of great harmony. It is like fire concealed within wood, originally at rest, but once drilling wood ignites it, the flames erupt and can burn away the very body—this is what is meant by "disaster arises and must harm oneself." How can this be forcibly drilled and attacked with private cleverness? To subdue it, nothing but the metal within water will suffice. The nature of wood is light and floating, while the nature of metal is heavy and settling. The wood-mercury is inherently restless, but upon encountering metal-lead, it naturally submits. At the gates of the six roots, it is restrained everywhere, and only then can consciousness be transformed into wisdom, emotions returned to nature, the water of stillness become profound, and the fire of wisdom eternally bright. Anger is not curbed but curbs itself; desire is not blocked but blocks itself, and thus it returns to quiescent unmoving. Once metal restrains wood, water restrains fire—how could there be any further disaster? This is the marvelous inversion of the Golden Elixir.

The Golden Elder is originally the son of the eastern household,
sent to the western neighbor to lodge and be born.
If you recognize and summon him to return and be nurtured,
pair him with the maiden to form a marital bond.
This chapter speaks of introducing lead into mercury. In the primordial *Xiyi*, Li is originally in the east and Kan in the west, hence the image of the eastern household and western neighbor. The Golden Elder is the true yang within Kan, which, because Qian was broken to become Li and sank into the Kun palace to form Kan, is it not like the son of the eastern household lodging with the western neighbor? Though true yang has flowed outward, its visage remains faintly discernible—it must be swiftly recognized. If one can use true intent as a matchmaker, extract the true yang from Kan, and pair it with the true yin within Li, the two substances return to the earthen crucible. The nature of metal and the essence of wood naturally harmonize, and the Golden Elixir is achieved—is this not like pairing the maiden to give birth to an infant? This, too, is the marvelous inversion.

The maiden wanders, each with her own direction—
the path ahead must be short, the path behind must be long.
When she returns, she enters the Yellow Dame’s abode,
to marry the Golden Elder as her old husband.
This chapter speaks of introducing mercury into lead. The flowing pearl within Li is likened to the postnatal heart, whose nature delights in movement, coming and going without fixed time, lingering in external realms, unwilling to retreat and conceal itself—like a woman fond of wandering. Yet it is originally one essence, now divided into six. Harmonizing the six roots and six dusts, it races day and night in whatever direction it faces—when will it ever rest? Unaware that engaging with realms invites transgressions, while retreating and concealing brings peace and a place to settle. It is like a woman whose days in her mother’s home should be short, and whose days in her husband’s home should be long—she naturally has a fixed place to establish herself and her life.
